turns.speaker: YAMAMOTO
turns.text: We have achieved surprise, but their carriers are not in port.  I don't like this.

turns.speaker: GENDA
turns.text: We have a fighter screen up, in case we are attacked, Admiral.

turns.speaker: YAMAMOTO
turns.text: We must go ahead.  This is our moment.

turns.speaker: GENDA
turns.text: We have achieved complete surprise!  The first wave is returning, the second is attacking now, and we have lost only a few planes.  We can launch a third wave, Admiral.

turns.speaker: YAMAMOTO
turns.text: The second wave has not returned.  And we have no idea where their carriers are. What is the damage report?

turns.speaker: GENDA
turns.text: If we launch the third wave and annihilate their fuel depots, we destroy their ability to operate in the Pacific for at least a year!

turns.speaker: YAMAMOTO
turns.text: And if we fail, and lose our carriers, we destroy our ability to fight them at all.  As soon as the second wave returns, we will withdraw.

turns.speaker: ROOSEVELT
turns.text: What if the Japanese did invade?

turns.speaker: GENERAL MARSHALL
turns.text: We've done studies.  We're confident we would turn them back eventually...after they'd gotten as far as Chicago.

turns.speaker: GENERAL MARSHALL
turns.text: We have bombed Tokyo, Mr. President. Radio Tokyo interrupted it's own broadcast to make the announcement.

turns.speaker: ROOSEVELT
turns.text: Have the planes made it to China?

turns.speaker: GENERAL MARSHALL
turns.text: There've been some complications, Sir. The Chinese didn't receive our request for homing beacons until is was too late to get them set.  And the planes had to take off so early they may lack fuel to make the mainland anyway.

turns.speaker: ROOSEVELT
turns.text: So those brave men are flying blind and running out of fuel.

turns.speaker: GENERAL MARSHALL
turns.text: The Chinese are sending out search parties to try to find the crews before the Jap patrols do, if any of the planes make it.

turns.speaker: ROOSEVELT
turns.text: God help them.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Leapin' Jesus!

turns.speaker: RAFE
turns.text: The struts are loose, the hydraulics are leaking, and the electrical system's shorting out in the cockpit.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Well which of those three ya want fixed?

turns.speaker: RAFE
turns.text: All of 'em.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: If ye'd wanted a bloody Cadillac ya should'a stayed in the bloody States!

turns.speaker: RAFE
turns.text: And if you don't give me a plane that can handle combat, you better start learning to speak German.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Fook ya!

turns.speaker: RAFE
turns.text: Learn English, then!

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Fook ya dooble!

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: I have'na been able ta --

turns.speaker: RAFE
turns.text: Crank her!

turns.speaker: NISHIKURA
turns.text: So you join us, Admiral.  Some of us thought your education at an American university would make you too weak to fight the Americans.

turns.speaker: YAMAMOTO
turns.text: If knowledge of opponents and careful calculation of danger is taken as weakness then I have misunderstood what it means to be Japanese.

turns.speaker: NISHIKURA
turns.text: The time has come to strike!  Or to sit and let the Americans cut off our oil and our future.  I know what you whisper to the others, Yamamoto -- that the Americans are strong.  Yet look at their leader.

turns.speaker: NISHIKURA
turns.text: You have something to say, Yamamoto?

turns.speaker: YAMAMOTO
turns.text: The Council knows I have opposed fighting the Americans.  No matter how great our resolve, they have resources beyond ours. If we must go to war, there is only one way -- deal them a blow from which it will take them years to recover.  In that time we can conquer all of the Pacific, and they will have no choice but to ask for peace.

turns.speaker: NISHIKURA
turns.text: You see us as capable of such a blow?

turns.speaker: YAMAMOTO
turns.text: The Americans themselves have made it possible.  We will annihilate them in a single attack -- at Pearl Harbor.

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: Hello, Lilla!

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Peggy Sue!

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: Quite a bit more rain than usual this year. I hope it doesn't spoil the rhubarb.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: I've already got some in. I was thinking of making a pie for dinner tonight.  How would you like that?

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: What's it going to be, Elizabeth? Seventyfive? Eighty?

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: I'm not telling.

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: I've been trying to drag it out of her for years.  You know, dreams are fascinating business. 'Specially where you see the future.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: What's Peggy Sue going to do at your lodge meeting?

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: It's her 18th birthday, I want to show her off.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Do you believe in all of that?

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: Well, I like to speculate. This book I'm reading right now, a woman in Colorado says she lived in Ireland a hundred and fifty years ago. Her name was Bridey Murphy- and she gives names and dates and where she lived. She was hypnotized. Big bestseller.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I remember that book!  Grandpa, Grandma, I want to tell you something.

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: It's gonna rain again. Every time I wash the car, it rains.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: That never changes.  You know, when you and Grandma are gone, the family's gone. I never see the cousins anymore.

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: It's your grandma's strudel that's kept this family together.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Grandpa, if you had a chance to do it all again, what would you do?

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: I'd take better care of my teeth.

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: Let's go.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Goodbye, Grandma.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What does Grandma think you do at your meetings?

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: Stag movies. Smokers.

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: I may be an old fool, but I think we can help you.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I hope so. At least I got to see you and Grandma.  Has it ever worked before?

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: The last one was six hundred years ago. It's about time for another one.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Do you have to wear that hat?

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: It wouldn't be a lodge without hats.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Where were you? You said you'd be back at twelve.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: This is my old friend Carol.. I told you about her.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: r was worried about you  You didn't even call. You're always on my case if I don't call..

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: How do you like my hair?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: It looks great. Don't change the subject. You know how busy Saturdays are. And I can't do the icing. I always mess up the roses. You're not being very responsible.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: But I want you and Scott to understand.  Do you think he loves Janet? Maybe he's smashed too many fortune cookies.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Come on Mom. Give him a break. He's missing the reunion because of you. You know he wants to go.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Then we'd both have a miserable time. What do you think?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Hey, you're a hip chick. You look like you stepped right out of Life magazine. Any time you want to borrow it again, just ask.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Borrow?! This was my dress.  Maybe it's a mistake. What if I'm the only one? I don't even want to go. Everybody's just going to say...  Hi.. Where's Crazy Charlie?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Mom, lots of people are separated and divorced.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Not from the guy with the lowest prices in town.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I feel ridiculous. Maybe I should go home and change.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Why are you so nervous? What is the matter with you today?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I don't know. Reunions do funny things to people.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Carol!

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Peggy Sue!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: 1 just did it for the reunion. I thought it would be fun.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: You're probably the only one who could carry it off.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Welcome to the singles scene.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I don't know how you do it. I've never even dated anybody but Charlie.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: You just have to remember... men are like houses and trade upwards... I thought you had a pretty good marriage.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: We did for a long time. We just got married too young, and ended up blaming each other for missing out on things.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: So he started having affairs, and you got depressed.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: You should have left here years ago, like I did.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It's not the place. I don't buy that.  Trapped in the same town forever. The price she would pay for her teenage lust.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: After you got knocked up, my mother didn't want me to talk to you. She thought it was contagious.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh, it's not so bad. I have two wonderful kids, my own business.  Still, knowing what I know now, if I had the chance to do it all over again, I'd sure do things a lot differently.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Wouldn't we all.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Hi, Peggy. God, that Walter Getz	can still dance.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Your first boyfriend. What do you think? Any sparks left?

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Who knows. Remember...  Whatever Walter wants...

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: The only one?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Well, besides Charlie, of course.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: They're waiting. Come on.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I can't. It's all too much.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Go on. You can do it.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Where is it?

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Were taking you back to the nurse.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Maddy, what did you do to your hair?

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: We're going to take you home.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: That's okay. I'm sure I'll remember the way.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: I'll call you Later.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yes. Let's stay in touch.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I don't get it.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: That's because you' re not a total moron like they are.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: He is kind of cute, isn't he?

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Yeah. You're so lucky. He really loves you, too. He's always telling Walter how wonderful you are.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: He does?

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: All right. What's the scoop?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: On what?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Did you memorize the whole book or only the good parts?

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Just what you underlined.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You're kidding...? Carol, you have beautiful hair.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Come on. What's with you and Michael?

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: I bet Dolores told Charlie.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: That loudmouthed little bitch~

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Okay. But let's have a girls night soon. Maybe a pajama party.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Aren't we a little old for that?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: It's that jerk Walter.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: After Charlie told Walter that he broke up with you because he wanted to play the field, Walter decided he should do the same thing.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Welcome to the singles' scene.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: What a I going to do for the rest of my life? I don't have a boyfriend anymore.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Look, Carol, maybe Walter's done you a big favor. You always said you wanted to get out of town. Go for it. And be happy, goddamnit, I'm rooting for you.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Lucky lady. Hi.

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: Michael Fitzsimmons! Is he here?

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: Can you believe I want to marry that dork.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Why do guys do such stupid things?

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Charlie really has a great voice.

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: Maybe they'll be the next Dion and the Belmonts.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: I hear she does more than talk with her mouth.

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: That's disgusting!

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: ) Oh, Maddy, grow up. It says in LOVE WITHOUT FEAR that "the tongue kiss as a means of genital stimulation is widely practiced and has much to commend it". Page eightysix.

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: Peggy Sue!

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: You better watch out for her. She's after Charlie.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Don't be silly. It's Saturday. Date night!

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: Yeah. I've gotta go. Arthur's picking me up soon.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: And we're here on the couch...

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Don't say that...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: We're here on the sofa bed...

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Charlie...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...to record how much we love each other. Sitting beside me is the cutest majorette in the history of the world. And she would Like to say something.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Come on Peggy. Say what we rehearsed.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I can't. I'm too embarrassed.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: But you love me don't you?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yeah. Come on Charlie, turn it off.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: And nothing will ever change that.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: There's something pathetic parked in front of my house.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Come off it, Peggy. And what do you mean your house? This is my house. I paid for it, I'm still paying for it.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm still waiting for the mortgage check.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I mailed it to you on Wednesday.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Well, today's Saturday and it's still not here.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Jesus, Peggy. Take it easy. I'm not used to that stuff. You always did the bills. Blame the damn post office.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You got a Tab?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I don't buy them anymore. You were the only one who drank them.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You don't want them? They're going to make a big comeback any minute. Mark my words, these lamps are going to...

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I know. Put Scott through college.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I'll think of a way to sell, them.  One day.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Are you taking Janet to the reunion tonight?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I'm not going.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I vant to suck your blood. I also vant to suck your Twinkie.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Charlie! Am I dead?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: No. You are the undead. You will live forever if you give me your Twinkie.  Come on, let's have it. You hate them anyway.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: How do you feel?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Pretty strange.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Not now, Charlie. I've got a headache. Get used to the word. Roll it around your tongue for a years.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hey, I can take a hint. You look great today.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You drive like a maniac!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I call this the staccato.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Not that I'm glad you were sick, but I had a chance to do some thinking last night.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh yeah?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You know. About what we said on Tuesday. It makes a lot of sense.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Refresh my memory.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: How could you forget? We talk about seeing other people and you forget?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Maybe I blocked it out.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I can understand that.. But please don't start crying again.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: It's not going to be forever. I figure three years is long enough. I can see it the music pans out.  And right after graduation we should start seeing other people. Kind of comparison shop before we settle down and get married. Know what I mean?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Why wait?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Well, we got the prom coming up, all these parties. We shouldn't upset our parents?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: They'll learn to live with it.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Want me to drive you home later?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Would you?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Would I?!! Why I oughta...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Looking good out there.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I noticed you were giving me the silent treatment at lunch. I guess I deserved it. I've been thinking about my three year plan and I think it's unworkable. I must have been delirious.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I thought it had a lot of merit.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: In the abstract maybe. Get a grip on yourself! But when I imagine you going out with other guys, I feel... ah...

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Rejected, worthless, miserable.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah. Like that.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Where did you get that sweater?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Great, isn't it?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It's really Fifties. You sort of clash with the world.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hey! What's the fun of being a teenager if you can't dress weird? And we're going to have fun tonight, right?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Right. I promised my mother.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Is this slow enough for you?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Charlie, how are you?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I'm fine Peggy Sue. And how are you? Are we talking on the phone? Are we pen pals?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Seriously. What's it like to be eighteen?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Charlie, what do you think of Richard Norvik?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Is he gonna help you with that physics stuff?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: He's trying.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hey! Who needs physics when we've got chemistry?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Come on, let's dance.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: There isn't a girl in school that can hold a candle to you..

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You're pretty charming when you want to be.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah I know.  But I don't have to flatter you.  It just feels right. You're the perfect girl for me.  As in is, was and always will be.  I'm glad dancing was invented.  You know the first dances were rituals. Like fertility rites.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Mmm. This is nice.  I always loved the way you kiss.  I missed you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Your eyes look like silver pools of moonlight.  And the tide rushes in.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You really love me, don't you?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You know I do.  I even wrote you into my will.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Charlie, let's make love.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What?! You mean sex?! Intercourse?  You want to have intercourse! Last weekend you said... What time is it?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: A lot's happened since last weekend.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: But you're the one who wanted to wait till we got married. And you were right. We should wait.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I probably meant it when I said it.  Doesn't Lucky Chuckie want to come out?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You know. Your love machine... the throbbing thrill hammer... your thing!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You mean my wang? Listen, it's running real late.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: This is a mistake. We better forget it.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You're damn right! Jesus! Peggy! You sure know how to spoil a mood.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm sorry Charlie.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Save it.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What do you know about classical music?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Nothing.. Selling is selling.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Charlie. About last nights..

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Forget it. I've been thinking. Girls must go through that stuff too. Sometimes when I look at you I feel like an animal. Maybe my dad's right. Teenagers are nuts.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: But I'm not. I'm a grown woman with a lifetime of emotional experiences you couldn't possibly understand.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah, I know. Girls mature faster than guys. But last night, I was the one who put on the brakes. And you know why?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Because nothing else matters. That's the great thing about love. Every time we argue, every time something goes wrong, and I know that I'm not perfect either, things just work out better in the end. Cause you're my baby and I love you.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What am I going to do with you?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Don't be cruel to a heart that's true.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Charlie. I just had the strangest dream.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I have to talk to you..

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Let's go down to the basement.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I want to know what's going on. Dolores told me that you and that scuzzball Michael Fitzsimmons...

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I bumped into him after you dropped me off Last night. I didn't feel like going home, so we went for a ride.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Then it's true, dammit! I had a miserable time tonight 'cause of you. When the Monotones did "Book of Love  Chapter Four you break up, won't you give it just one more chance..." I'm thinking Did we break up? 'Cause if we did, I don't even know about it!. I thought we cleared all that up yesterday. Did that Maynard G. Beatnik give you what you wanted?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You know I never could stand your sarcasm.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You're going to blow it, Peggy Sue. Nobody treats Charlie Bodell like this.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: And why do you always refer to yourself in the third person, like Napoleon? How come it always turns into an argument with you?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Look, I've got the hair, got the eyes, got the teeth, I got the car. I'm the lead singer, I'm the man.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Charlie,. I've been trying to postpone this. But what's the point? It's over.  I don't want to hurt you. This is very hard for me. I'm doing this for both of us. I really want you to be happy.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I will be happy if I have you. I love you.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: That won't make any difference. We just can't live together. And you had the nerve to drive up with that bimbo Janet.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What are you talking about? Who's Janet?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I just can't trust you anymore.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What about everything I said to you this afternoon...

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: That's just it. You can always get to me. There's this window in my heart and every time I leave it open, you climb in. Unless I close it now, nothing's ever going to be different!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: But what has to be different?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Everything. I have a good head for business, I should be franchising the bakery. And I want you to give me your word that whatever happens, you'll go to college. And finish.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What! What about the group and my singing career? What about me?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm trying to save you years of frustration... waiting for a big break... no. Waiting for that big disappointment so you could blame it all on me.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You don't know zip! You think I'm going to end up selling appliances like my father? Chasing women around the store. I've got to give it a shot. Why are you trying to kill the two things that mean the most to me? Until yesterday you loved me and you loved us.  ) What the hell has changed? For two years I've done nothing but love you. I'll show you, I'm going to be just like Fabian!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What're you doing here?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I wanted to talk to you, and I have one last thing to take care of at school. Then I'm going to...  Good dog, Rusty. Good dog.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Rusty's dead. That's Ajax

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh. I guess I always liked Rusty better.  Could you give me a ride to school?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Sorry, the Blue Thunder's out of commission for a while.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Well, how about a walk, Charlie Bell..

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: How'd you know about that?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I was at Lena's last night. You were terrific.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Not terrific enough. What were you doing in that part of town? Who were you with?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What were You doing there? You never told me you were singing with an R and B group.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hey. I guess there's a lot of things we don't know about each other.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'd forgotten how much music meant to you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: That's real big of you.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Stop being defensive. I want to help you. I wrote a song for you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You're kidding. You wrote a song? Is it about a guilty girl and a trusting guy... she wants to hurt him, and he wonders why?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Not exactly, but with your great voice, it'll be a huge hit. Honest.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Fat chance. You know, Lee Wilkins came to hear me last night. He told me to forget it. You told me to forget it. My parents tell me to forget it.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Just take a look at it.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: If you took the trouble to write it, then sure, I'll take a look at it. But I'm beginning to think that maybe there's more to life than music. I wonder if people would still like me if I stopped being Mr. Excitement?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Does this mean you like me again?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It means I care about you and what happens to you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: That's all I wanted to hear. 'Cause I'm never going to give up on us. It's easy to fall apart in a crisis. It's easy to be selfish and say goodbye and good luck. But this is more than love. This is a mental decision. Just wait till tomorrow, when you see your birthday present. Then you'll understand.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Forget it, it'll never work.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Okay. Listen, I cancelled the tickets for Fabian. I thought it would be better for your birthday to eat at a nice restaurant, Chez Tres.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What the hell did you do that for? What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I was trying to save you. They were going to vaporize you.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Don't be ridiculous! They're just a bunch of harmless old men. My grandfather was in there.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You're going to listen to me.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Let me got! Where are you taking me?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Right here. Now sit down.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Look. I wanna tell you. I forgive you for everything. I know what you've been going through. You're just scared. I was scared, too, but I'm not anymore.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: How could you possibly know what I've been going through?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What do you mean you and my father decided? Who the hell are you to plan my life? Let's get married and live happily ever after. Bullshit. I got knocked up. I had to marry you. I never had a choice.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You betrayed me, Charlie. You were never there for me or the children. And now you come and tell me, "Peggy, you're scared." Of course I'm scared. If you knew what I knew you'd be scared shitless.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You're crazy! You're really out of your mind!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I might be crazy, but I'm not crazy enough to marry you twice. There's a lot of things I can't change. I can't even think about them. I tried. But I couldn't even help Rosalie.  I don't want to be bitter. I'm a naturally optimistic person. But you took advantage of that.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Will you take me back to my grandparents?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh, Charlie.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: It opens, too. Look inside.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I think we should get out of here. It's going to rain.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Do you think anybody in the Fifties ever made love on a bed?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What the hell is that?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Peggy! Where're you going? Come back!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I've got to go now.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: But I love you. I'll love you forever.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'll love you, too, Charlie. I'll love you for twenty years.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Come back to me.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm trying.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: . Peggy Sue, I love you, and I need you Peggy Sue...

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Charlie? Was I dead?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I thought you were...for a while.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You look awful, like you haven't slept in days. And so old.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: But happy. Very happy, Peggy Sue.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Charlie, I thought I knew everything about you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I wanted to apologize. I can't live without you.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What about Janet?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: That's over. I got tired of translating everything. She thought the Big Hopper was a hamburger.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It couldn't be me.  I hardly knew him.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I'll just set it right here.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Charlie, I had a strange experience.  I went back to high school. And I spent a lot of time with you.  And you and Walter and Leon were singing "I Wonder Why".

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Oh, God, Dion.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You were terrific.  And I kept trying to push you away but you wouldn't give up.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I'll never give up.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Then hold me.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I loved you since the day I met you, and I haven't stopped.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Don't try to charm me, Charlie Bodell.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Listen, I don't expect all the troubles between us can just vanish away. But I would do what I can...

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Hello, Charlie.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hello, sir. How are things at the hat store?

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Fine, thanks. Come on in. I want to talk to you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: She seems confused, irresponsible, overemotional. My wife says that's the way girls act sometimes.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yes, sir. But that's what I like about her. She's not like all the other girls at school.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Charles, in spite of your adolescent infatuation with music, we've always regarded you a a fine young man. We've trusted you with our daughter.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yes, sir. Trust is a twoway street. In the past two years I've been pleased to note that you and Mrs. Kelcher have, uh, fulfilled your sacred trust of being good parents to the, uh, woman I plan to take off your hands.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: We think this party might cheer her up. Just make sure you know what's expected of you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What would that be, sir?

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Show her a good time, but for God's sake restrain yourself.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Did you study for the test?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Test?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Carol and I saw you with that creep, Richard, today.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: First of all, Richard is not a creep. He happens to be an exceptional person. If any of you gave him half a chance, you'd find that out.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: God, Peggy, you're so unformed you're practically fetal. You're just taking pity on him 'cause he has no friends.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Dolores, can't you be a little kinder to people? You don't even know the boy. If you weren't so neurotic and insecure, maybe you'd shut up for a while and show some compassion.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Are you for real?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Touchy, touchy!
